fields.description: CFBundleDisplayName in Info.plist is empty. Causes SourceTree to show up blank in Activity Monitor and elsewhere.
fields.summary: CFBundleDisplayName is empty

fields.description:
For a certain Mercurial repo I have, somehow the email addresses used for commits are being mixed up. I only want my work email ("kwojniak") to be used, but somehow it's also using my personal one ("kainjow").

I confirmed through 'hg log -r XX' and with another developer with his repo that my personal email is being used, so it's not a SourceTree display bug.

If it helps, all my Mercurial repos use my work email, and all Git repos use my personal one. Attached is a screenshot showing some settings and the repo showing both emails.

I don't have this issue with other repos, just this one.
fields.summary: Email addresses getting mixed up

fields.description: It'd be nice to show the user name and email in the commit window, especially since it can be customized per project, and it's not always clear which user is being used for a project.
fields.summary: Show user info in Commit sheet

fields.description: The columns displayed in any window should be customizable. The standard way is to provide a contextual menu on the columns themselves that allow choosing which columns show (see Finder windows).
fields.summary: Allow customizing which columns are displayed

fields.description:
I'm using SVN through git-svn and SourceTree. It all works OK, except when I would like to merge two branches. I know that git-style merges are not supported by SVN, but SVN does have the *svn:mergeinfo* property, which _git-svn_ (and SourceTree) efectively use to draw nice graphs of merges between two SVN branches.

Feature request: let SourceTree set *svn:mergeinfo* correctly when merging two SVN branches.

For now, I have made a proof-of-concept script and used it successfully to repeatedly merge two SVN branches using only git-svn as the frontend.
The script can be found:

http://j.mp/10lXWEZ
fields.summary: SVN mergeinfo

fields.description: In the "Files in the working tree" pane, if you right-click on a file that has changes, there should be an option to discard all changes. This way multiple files containing changes could be selected, and you could discard all those changes, rather than having to click "discard" individually for each file in the preview pane to the right of the files in the working tree.
fields.summary: Discard All Option

fields.description:
I had a git tag on a particular commit. Then I modified the tag to include notes by executing this:

git tag usage-schema-1.17.2 usage-schema-1.17.2 -f -m "Some message"

After the above command, Source Tree no longer shows usage-schema-1.17.2 tag. But I know it's there. Gitk showed it and the Source Tree nav bar also showed it.
fields.summary: git tag is there but not shown

fields.description:
When the Full Log Output dialog window is shown, the OK button has the blue highlight around it as if it is the first responder but pressing the Return key doesn't apply to the OK button.  Strangely the Esc key will make the dialog go away even though there isn't a "Cancel" button.

Another issue with this is that if you press the Esc key too soon, before the command is completed, it attempts to cancel the git command instead.
fields.summary: OK in Full Log Output window isn't first responder

fields.description:
When a git command is issued, there is an option to show the Full Log Output.  Sometimes I would like to see the command/output but I'm not fast enough to click the button before the dialog disappears.
There is a preference setting to always show the output window but most of the time, I don't want to see it, and dismissing it has other issues (bug report to follow)

I would like to ask for a new feature to be added to have the command/output be removed from the dialog window and have it sent elsewhere so I can view it if I want.  A couple of suggestions are 
- A log file
-- ~/Library/Logs/SourceTree/REPONAME dir or the repo .git dir
-- with a set max number of lines so it doesn't grow out of control
- A sub-pane in the SourceTree Repository window
-- Similar to the Debug Area pane of an XCode project window
-- Limited history to last x number of commands run
-- Cleared when the SourceTree app is quit

I've attached a screenshot mockup of what I'm thinking of from the XCode Debug Area idea.  The log pane can be shown/hidden by clicking the pane selector button above the log pane.  In the mockup image, I've expanded the existing sidebar selector to include a lower area option.

I'd also like to see an option where the log is automatically shown when a command is sent but is automatically hidden after x seconds when the command completes.

I really hope you can make this suggestion happen.  I would like to see the commands and output but the current implementation is a bit frustrating to use all the time.
fields.summary: Constant log area instead of one-off output window

fields.description:
I routinely make errors while resolving merge conflicts due to the seemingly inscrutable naming of the “{{Resolve Using Theirs}}” and “{{Resolve Using Mine}}” commands. In particular, the meaning of “mine” and “theirs” seems to be semantically variable depending on the context in which the conflict has occurred.

For example, “mine” and “theirs” may take on opposite meanings depending whether I'm applying a stash, doing a pull with rebase, a merge, etc.  This breaks my brain every time I have to deal with it, because I invariably choose the wrong one based on my interpretation of the language.  (Instead I now invariably duck out to an external merge tool and deal with it visually, even though I know it's extra busywork.)

It would be vastly superior if SourceTree could provide contextually-appropriate labels for these commands, such as:

* {{Resolve Using Stash}} and {{Resolve Using Head}} (when applying a stash)
* {{Resolve Using Remote}} and {{Resolve Using Local}} (when pulling with rebase from a remote)
* {{Resolve Using $branchname1}} and {{Resolve Using $branchname2}} (when merging locally)
* etc.
fields.summary: “Resolve Using {Mine|Theirs}” naming can lead to confusion and error
Naming of "rebase current changes onto [branch]" context menu is misleading.

fields.description:
I use SourceTree to deploy to Heroku, and git push in this case takes just long enough so that I want to go an do something else until it finishes. It would be useful for SourceTree to play a sound or trigger some sort of alert to let me know that the process has finished.

I usually expand the detail view when doing this type of push, so that I have handy access to the log in case the deploy fails. If triggering an alert every time is too annoying for the user, maybe only triggering an alert when the detail view is expanded, or perhaps when SourceTree is out of focus would be a better solution?
fields.summary: Play a sound or alert when push completes

fields.description:
I have one big mercurial repo with 22 git subrepos in "src/vendor". For some reason SourceTree is trying to open my project's root directory as a git repo and silently fails because it is under `hg`. The worst thing is that SourceTree is trying again and again with no regard to failure – so on each UI refresh I can see a lot of new error lines with in my Console.app:

{noformat}
5/6/13 3:43:08.200 AM SourceTree[9584]: Could not obtain git dir, /Users/yuryproshchenko/Documents/Projects/odesk/rackmaze is not a git repo.
5/6/13 3:43:08.202 AM SourceTree[9584]: Could not obtain git dir, /Users/yuryproshchenko/Documents/Projects/odesk/rackmaze is not a git repo.
5/6/13 3:43:08.393 AM SourceTree[9584]: Could not obtain git dir, /Users/yuryproshchenko/Documents/Projects/odesk/rackmaze is not a git repo.
{noformat}

I've recorded 1 minute screencast with SourceTree, Console and Activity Monitory as major actors. Here is a timeline:

2 sec – My working copy is clean and has no changes
10 sec – my .hgsub file with 22 git sub repositories 
22 sec – saving one of the files from under mercurial control
next 40 seconds SourceTree is updating UI and I'm trying to show that with Console.app and Activity Monitor.app
60 sec – "Uncommitted changes" finally appears in Source Tree

w/o Quicktime SourceTree refreshes UI not much faster and still consumes CPU very aggressively (~120-160%) for 20-30 seconds.
fields.summary: SourceTree 1.5.8 errors when managing mercurial + git subrepos

fields.description: In Hg Flow menu for feature branches please add button that merges "develop" branch into current feature branch.
fields.summary: Add "Merge develop to this branch" button to Hg Flow menu

fields.description: See attached screen shot. Tried restarting SourceTree and it keeps happening. To bring up this window press Cmd+Opt+Esc.
fields.summary: SourceTree app name does not appear in Force Quit Applications window

fields.description: I often want to view the log history for a file, but there's not a direct way to do it. The ability to drag a file onto the Dock icon and have its history window pop up would be very convenient.
fields.summary: Drag file onto Dock icon to view history

fields.description: Git projects have a "Commit" column but for Mercurial there isn't an equivalent. There should be a Changeset column for Mercurial so the log for a cset can be quickly looked up.
fields.summary: Mercurial: show changeset in its own column

fields.description:
Kiln recently added support to access your repositories with both Git and Mercury. I have been having trouble getting Mercury to work and I find Git easier to work with having contributed to Github a lot.
However when ever I punch in my Kiln details, Source-tree automatically detects it as a Mercury client, when in fact it supports both 
In order for me to use git with Kiln and Source Tree I have to clone the repository via a CLI or another program and then add it in manually into Source Tree via the Add working copy command. There is simply no way for me to go "yes I know its a Mercury Client, Source Tree but I'ld rather use Git if thats okay with you?" or even for Source Tree to go "Hey dude, this repository supports both Git and Mercury which one do you want to use ? "
fields.summary: Add Support for Kiln with Git

fields.description:
When using SourceTree it comes up a message like "Askpass wants to use your confidential information stored in 'bitbucket.org' in your keychain'

It's because this is the hook to SSH_ASKPASS and the prompt that shows up is from OS X which automatically uses the name of the helper tool in the dialog.

Perhaps it could be changed to SourceTreePasswordHelper or something in order to avoid confusion.
fields.summary: Change "Askpass" Messages to Use a More Recognisable Name

fields.description: Crash report in attachment.
fields.summary: Source Tree crashes when opening

fields.description:
See comments in AAC here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/158312/sourcetree-fails-to-open-repository-after-converting-it-from-hg-git

Presumed browser.plist not updating when reloading - best way to fix would be to manually edit the browser.plist file although not preferential. This also seems to permanently affect the submodules of a repo even if you've removed and re-added the bookmark.
fields.summary: Converting repository causes bookmark/repo issues from SourceTree

fields.description:
STSP: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-390

This is to do with authenticating a submodule. It could be linked to the recent port specification issue which has been resolved for 1.6, need more information from the user.
fields.summary: Opt-in pref for listing team-level repo's (for the team you're in)

fields.description:
With the latest beta I have been experiencing a few hiccups when SourceTree does a refresh. From time to time this takes several seconds, using 4 or more "cores" and also requiring a good part of kernel time.
This results in a really bad UX (unresponsiveness, choppy cursor movements) inside SourceTree and other applications.

The problems are caused by manual and automatic refreshes, but are sometimes happening in when SourceTree is in the background. I'm sorry I can't provide any further details, but I haven't been able to find a pattern, yet.
fields.summary: High CPU usage during refresh

fields.description:
This is the second time it's happened to me now. Basically if you've got some changes you think should be in another branch you shelve those changes (you could create a patch). Switch to the branch you want those changes on and then unshelve. Hey presto, you have a load of changes that weren't in that shelve. In my case I had added image files from another branch I'm working on in there, when I hit revert they went bad to a non-added state just as they would've if I had have been in that branch originally.

There must be a bug with shelve, or the way we handle it. This is in hg.
fields.summary: Shelve, switch branch, unshelve causes two shelves to be applied

fields.description:
Add ability to copy entire diff text, as you would get in a diff file OR as the represented diff in the diff view, so you can paste it wherever you want.

Requested via Twitter by Alexis Menard (@darktears): https://twitter.com/darktears/status/327779864042143744
fields.summary: "Copy to clipboard" from diff

fields.description: Reported via Twitter: https://twitter.com/intafon/status/327460988108554240
fields.summary: Spaces in "New Feature" dialog of gitflow

fields.description:
This report is against SourceTree 1.6.0b3

The interactive rebase UI is looking pretty good, but it's still hard to tell which commits are newer and which are older.  If you showed the commit date in the list of commits that would help a lot.  This is especially important because you're showing them in the *opposite* order compared to git's command-line interactive rebase UI.

Also, if you delete a commit it just vanishes with no way of undoing the change short of resetting the entire rebase.  It would be better to display the commit in red with a strikethrough to indicate it will be deleted, and change the delete button to "undelete."  That gives the user a clear view of all the changes that will occur before pressing the OK button.

TL;DR
* Show commit dates
* Undo functionality
* Show deleted commits
fields.summary: Improvements to interactive rebase UI

fields.description: It would be nice if the Push output could translate ANSI escape codes. Some of the output I get from my PaaS is in ANSI and I don't have an option to disable ANSI output.
fields.summary: Push output doesn't translate ANSI escape codes

fields.description:
The Push output colors could use some improvement.

Currently:

- git command is in blue (good)
- git stdOut is in red (bad, signifies error in most applications; black would be better)
- git stdErr is in red (bad, indistinguishable from stdOut; red would be better assuming above is changed)
- Completed successfully is in blue (okay, but green would be better)
fields.summary: Push output color

fields.description: When Hg Flow is initialised on a Mercurial repository and confirmed, it switches to the default branch. It should switch to the develop branch instead.
fields.summary: Hg Flow Switches to Default Branch Instead of Develop Branch

fields.description: If you look at the diff for a conflicted file in Git, the line numbers always start at zero regardless of where the changes are in the file.
fields.summary: Line numbers on conflicted files always start at 0
Icon in dock shows low resolution in retina display Macs

fields.description:
On MacOS X systems which have Path Finder installed and setup as the default app for handling folders, SourceTree should open the project folder in Path Finder rather than in Finder when clicking "Show in Finder" in the toolbar.

Meanwhile, an "Open in Path Finder" custom action can be created by using the `open` script with `$REPO` as parameters.
fields.summary: "Show in Finder" and Path Finder

fields.description:
We run a stash installation that requires client side TLS certificates for access.

SourceTree is unable to communicate with the stash installation in the hosted repository tab. While certainly a product of our installation choice, we'd love to be able to use SourceTree.

I would hope that an implementation would use certificates stored in the keychain, similar to how passwords for hosted repositories are stored there.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Support Stash Hosted Repositories that require client TLS certificates

fields.description:
This is for SourceTree 1.6.0b2, which Jira won't let me use as a version.
When you squash commits in the interactive rebase UI the default is to concatenate the second commit message directly onto the "base" commit message, (usually?) on one line. This is useless and annoying. It would be better to use a default that leaves the base commit message and appends the second message in a format like:

Before:
Base message: Fixed bug 47
second message: Whoops, I forgot something

Current behavior:
Fixed bug 47 Whoops, I forgot something

Desired message:
"""
Fixed bug 47 (+1 squashed commit)
Squashed commits:
[hash] Whoops, I forgot something
"""
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase: Default squashed commit message is useless

fields.description:
The "Squash with previous" button in the interactive rebase sheet causes the selected commit to be squashed with the next commit, chronologically speaking.
This is all pretty confusing because of the ambiguity of the word "previous", and also because the list of commits doesn't show a date or otherwise help the user understand what order the commits are being listed in. The command line version of git rebase -i shows commits with the oldest at the top and the newest at the bottom, so "previous" is unambiguous.

I would suggest making an extra effort to indicate the chronological order of commits, and respecting that order in "Squash with previous".
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase: "Squash with previous" squashes with next, not previous

fields.description: STSP-475 (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-475) is the original issue. I've confirmed this issue exists on my test machine using the OP test repo. Confirmed this happens with embedded Git.
fields.summary: Git reports file as untracked/tracked at the same time

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Clone a repository twice.
# Create a tag on the 1st repository and push to remote.
# Fetch the changes on the 2nd repository.
# Commit a change on the 1st repository.
# Delete the tag create previously and re-create it with the same name at the new commit.
# Push the changes to remote.
# Fetch the changes on the 2nd repository.

The tag is on the [earlier commit in the 2nd repository|^screenshot1.png].

This can be fixed by including the {{-t}} switch to the {{git fetch}} command.
fields.summary: Fetching From a Remote Git Repository Does Not Fetch Deleted Tags

fields.description:
As stated in AAC. Assigning to 1.6

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/158878/sourcetree-cloning-from-https-git-repo-with-sslverify-false
fields.summary: SSL setting being ignored on clone

fields.description: Kaleidoscope supports tabs. See if we can cause multiple tabs to open in one instance rather than multiple instances for each file when hitting external diff with multiple files selected in SourceTree.
fields.summary: Kaleidoscope tab support

fields.description: As title, if you select multiple files and hit external diff, the diff tool doesn't open
fields.summary: GRI doesn't allow external diff against multiple files

fields.description:
On a project with a naming convention for branches such as issue/<issue key> or stable-issue/<issue key> the drop down presentation of branches is unusable.

I need some way of filtering by substring rather than by start of string which I gather is offered by default in the UI component.
fields.summary: The branch selector (e.g. on checkout) is unusable when you have a large number of similarly named branches

fields.description:
SourceTree has many different file views: the one in the log view, the one in the file status view, and the one in the commit dialog, to name a few. These are all used in different ways, yet setting the view preferences on one (flat/tree/column, and show pending/all/etc.) affects the others.

In my log view and commit dialog, I quickly want to see all the changed files without having to expand subfolders, so I want a flat list of only unchanged files. Yet in the file status view, I want to view the file hierarchy as it exists on the disk, so I want a tree view showing all files.


Additionally, in tree view, SourceTree doesn't seem to remember which folders were expanded or not, and seems to err on the side of keeping folders closed. If I have a small number of files deep in the hierarchy (for example, a tree view showing only pending changes) this gets really annoying to navigate as I work in SourceTree, since I have to expand a bunch of folders repeatedly to see my desired data.
fields.summary: Different file views should remember different settings

fields.description:
At present, whenever the terminal is called from the App, it always passes the command to the same terminal tab, no matter what tab I have selected etc. For a single project, this isnt so much of an issue, but if you have multiple project open (eg about to commit and deploy multiple projects), then this is more of an irritant, and each project will simply try and steal terminal focus from the other.

This creates a rather confusing working environment, and I would rather the default behaviour (or a configuration option) to either have each terminal command launch a new instance, or to send the command to the topmost / active window/tab.

Im not too fussed if this is configurable in the app preferences, or via a terminal flag etc, as long as an option exists to separate the projects from sharing the same terminal window.
fields.summary: Stop different projects from opening in same terminal tab/window
In groups reflect pull / push info for projects

fields.description:
Reported by aras_p via Twitter: https://twitter.com/aras_p/status/324098822106128384

"Log selected" context menu item isn't working if you select a single file in Git file status view.
fields.summary: "Log selected" on single file in Git context menu item

fields.description:
While reviewing file changes, if scrolling down when reviewing a big chunk, then stage it, the view position is inconsistent.

It would be expected to be positioned at the beginning of next chunk instead of being way down as it is actually.

The bigger the chunk is, further down in the changes you are.
fields.summary: Inconsistent Scroll Position When Staging Chunks

fields.description: Currently, the Sign-Off checkbox is disabled by default. I would like to have an option to have it enabled it by default.
fields.summary: Add an option to make Sign-Off cheched by default

fields.description:
My first try for using GRI went like this:
squash two commits, edit message, click ok
resolve the conflict
Continue Rebase hangs up
Show Full Output:
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c "sequence.editor="/Applications/SourceTree (beta 1.6).app/Contents/Resources/stree_gri"" rebase --continue 
Vim: Warning: Output is not to a terminal
Vim: Warning: Input is not from a terminal

Clicked "Cancel" and it dumps a bunch of garbage which looks like it might be a Vim screen:

...blah                                                                       [0m[22;1H[1m[7m[1] .git/COMMIT_EDITMSG [gitcommit]                           1,1-1          All[1;5H[24;1H[0mVim: Caught deadly signal TERM
Vim: Finished.

Turns out I had specified vim as my editor in ~/.gitconfig.
Once I removed "editor = vim", the GRI with an edited message worked correctly!
This setting has been in mt .gitconfig for a long time, and this is the first time I've had trouble, so I'm guessing this is 1.6b1 specific, but maybe not.
fields.summary: Editing the message in an GRI hangs and throws and error

fields.description:
I just tried to set up my system in a somewhat more complicated mode:
Local Git Repository:
master and develop branch going to 'origin'
feature/* going to 'fork'
where origin points to an original github repository and fork points to a fork of that repository.
Now when I do a "Push to fork/feature/feature-name", Sourcetree creates a 'origin/feature/feature-name' branch instead and switches the tracking to that one.
This happens with 1.6.0b1 which unfortunately I cannot select below.
fields.summary: Tracking is switched when using multiple remotes

fields.description:
When committing a message like the following:
{noformat}
Class ABC
   Class DEF inherits from ABC
   Class GHI also inherits from ABC
{noformat}
 
[SourceTree strips all leading spaces|^screenshot1.png] from the commit/notes input on Mercurial repositories. This does [not happen in Git|^screenshot2.png].

This is the same as when using {{hg log}} and {{hg log -v}}.
fields.summary: Multiline Commit Message is Stripped for Mercurial Repositories

fields.description:
construct:
{code}
A   |origin/master| && |master|
| B |feature2|
|/
C
D   (merge D |feature1| to C |master|)
| \
| E
| F (merge |master| on |feature1| for integration test)
|/G
H | 
| I (merge |master| on |feature1| for integration test)
|/|
J | 
K | (<<<<<<<<< my new rebase point for |feature2| on the old |master|)
L | 
| M (forked |feature1|)
|/
N
O
{code}
or horizontally:
{code}
O---N---L---K---J-----H---------D---C---A master
     \           \      \      /     \ 
      M---–-------I---G---F---E       B   feature2
                              ^
                              ^feature1
{code}

# Now check out feature2.
# rebase feature2 on K

what is executed:
{code}
$ git co feature2
$ git rebase K [feature2]
{code}

what *should* be executed:
{code}
$ git co feature2
$ git rebase --onto K master [feature2]
{code}

the latter one is what the user expects.

*note*:
do NOT
{code}
$ git co feature2
$ git rebase --onto K [feature2]
{code}
^^ without hinting to the master branch

because this resets feature2 onto K but your changes in the branch are lost!


-----
background: I don't understand exactly WHY this happens because feature2 is not branched from feature1. seems to the cross-merge from master to feature1 caused this ... but this section from man paged helped to find that:
{code}Here is how you would transplant a topic branch based on one branch to another, to pretend that you forked the topic
branch from the latter branch, using rebase --onto.
First let's assume your topic is based on branch next. For example, a feature developed in topic depends on some
functionality which is found in next.
        o---o---o---o---o master
             \
              o---o---o---o---o next
                               \
                                o---o---o topic
We want to make topic forked from branch master; for example, because the functionality on which topic depends was
merged into the more stable master branch. We want our tree to look like this:
        o---o---o---o---o master
            | \
            | o'--o'--o' topic
             \
              o---o---o---o---o next
We can get this using the following command:
    git rebase --onto master next topic
Another example of --onto option is to rebase part of a branch. If we have the following situation:
                                H---I---J topicB
                               /
                      E---F---G topicA
                     /
        A---B---C---D master
then the command
     git rebase --onto master topicA topicB
 would result in:
                      H'--I'--J' topicB
                     /
                     | E---F---G topicA
                     |/
         A---B---C---D master
 This is useful when topicB does not depend on topicA.

{code}
fields.summary: Rebase onto instead of simple rebase

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new file
2. In SourceTree drag it from the working tree into the staging index
3. In Finder (or whatever) delete the file from your working tree
4. Back in SourceTree drag the file from the staging index to the working tree
5. Watch as SourceTree deletes your work without asking you first!

I had expected SourceTree to copy the file from the staging index to the working tree, thus restoring the file I'd (accidentally) deleted.  I now realise my understanding of what SourceTree would do was flawed.  However it would be nice if SourceTree asked you before actually deleting your work.

Please could you add a confirmation dialog between steps 4 and 5 in the above sequence?  A simple version would be to ask:

  Are you sure you want to delete XXX? Yes/No

Or maybe more usefully:

  Do you want to delete XXX or copy it to your working tree? Delete/Copy/Cancel

Thanks,
Mark
fields.summary: No delete confirmation when unstaging a file that's deleted in the working tree

fields.description: The help files need to be updated with new screenshots and retina screenshots. Old content needs to be updates to reflect any changes and new content needs to be added, for example, registration integration and GRI documentation.
fields.summary: Help Update

fields.description: If a user was looking at their GitHub or Bitbucket repository in SourceTree we need to be able to support a link to their repository through SourceTree somewhere. This could only be supported for repositories where we know the URL format meets a certain specification, however, and with there being so many hosting providers we couldn't possibly support all of them. Probably just the major ones, i.e. GH, BB, Stash, Kiln, maybe even Google's project hosting.
fields.summary: Support repository links to hosting provider of remote repo

fields.description:
I changed my bitbucket account password. When doing 'pull', I immediatly pressed OK. Then two password dialog popups appeared: one for the 'incoming changes' and one for the pull request. They block each other, I could choose only on of them, but choosing OK or cancel dit not have any effect. The other one was not selectable. Had to kill Sourcetree.
Next time I started I waited for the 'Incoming changes' to complete (and ask for the password) and then it went OK.
fields.summary: Double password dialog blocks program

fields.description:
There are filters for "Current Branch" and "All Branches" as well as filters for "Show Remote Branches" and "Hide Remote Branches".

I would like to be able to see all local branches *and* remote branches that are upstream from them (or that they are tracking).

Right now, if you select "Current Branch" and "Show Remote Branches", you see all remote branches that are upstream from the current checked out branch.  I essentially want this for all branches I have locally (the output of git branch).
fields.summary: Ability to view only branches I have checked out locally and the upstream branches they track

fields.description: When a local branch has been deleted and then I control-click on a remaining branch before choosing Push, the sheet for pushing appears, but still lists the deleted branch.  If I tick the deleted branch and choose to push, Git reports in the output window that the reference of the source doesn't exist, as you would expect.  But the branch shouldn't be listed at all on the push sheet.
fields.summary: Deleted local branches are still shown when choosing to push to the remote

fields.description: If you're already editing a message in GRI then you can still edit other fields hitting the "Edit message" button along the button and selecting other rows. We should completely disable the STOutlineView when the message is open after double clicking on a row (or simply opening the message bubble)
fields.summary: Editing other rows allowed in GRI when currently editing

fields.description: When hitting the 'move down' button when a item has children and they're open, when the parent item is the last element and you continue to hit 'move down' it will move the selection down to the children, which it shouldn't be allowed to do. This is only minor as it doesn't change anything in any way.
fields.summary: GRI move up/down buttons on last element with children

fields.description:
propose improve Japanese phrase.

"オープン選択したバージョン"
should be:
"選択したバージョンを開く"
fields.summary: Improve Japanese phrase

fields.description:
Add option to trigger git's -S flag in commits and, more importantly, tags.

See ftp://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-tag.html for more information.
fields.summary: Add GPG Signing Support

fields.description:
When looking at submodule changes SourceTree currently shows something like this:

-Subproject commit d355bd9dbf367a29e8b97c6042da14dfe4375aa1
+Subproject commit 55cc1affd9315d6ae85cecd2a022bac216612487

Instead I'd like to see commit description, author, date and changed files:

-Subproject commit [d355bd9] works fine, Nico, yesterday
+Subproject commit [55cc1af] works even better, Nico, today

#	modified:   cfg/settings.h
#	modified:   main.cpp
fields.summary: Git submodule diff should show more than SHA-1

fields.description: As requested via Twitter: https://twitter.com/nascode/status/320173763259924480
fields.summary: Progress bar when pulling/pushing

fields.description:
See discussions here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/154204/git-submodule-update-on-branch-switch

Basically need an opt-in option in the prefs on the Git tab to have an option whereby you can checkout the HEAD of a submodule regardless of what commit you're checking out on any branch. This is only available in Git any way so can't be done in Mercurial.
fields.summary: Opt-in preference for checking out HEAD of submodule in Git

fields.description:
I changed my git pull preference to 'use rebase instead of merge by default' (see first screen shot)
When I use the pull icon in the toolbar the 'Rebase instead of Merge' checkbox is pre ticked for me as per my settings. (shot 2)
But, when I right click on the branch name in the sidebar and select pull, the 'Rebase instead of Merge' is not pre ticked. (shot 3)
fields.summary: Pulling from the side bar does not respect rebase preferences

fields.description:
The location of the Araxis Merge compare utility has moved within the Araxis Merge application bundle in Araxis Merge 2013.4283. SourceTree reports that it cannot find the Araxis compare tools even when the new location is on the PATH.

It is possible to configure Araxis Merge as the diff and merging tool using the "Other" option and specifying the new location of the utilities within the application bundle as the Diff/Merge command.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not work with Araxis Merge version 2013.4283

fields.description: In the "Date" column of the log table, it would be nice to be able to switch to relative dates like "1 hour ago", "1 day ago" and so on. Absolute dates sometimes are hard to work with and hard to quickly parse.
fields.summary: Support relative dates

fields.description:
The history graph is sometimes a bit hard to "read" because it's too dense on the horizontal axis (at least for my taste). For this I still use MacHg whose graph is "lighter".

It would be nice if the horizontal spacing of the history graph could be configured somehow. An intuitive and obvious way might be to adjust the spacing according to the table column width, but the downside would be that you couldn't use the column width to create a spacing between the graph and the log text.
fields.summary: History graph is too dense.

fields.description:
In a repo:

1. create a representitive file
ls -al > somefile

2. make a symlink to it
ln -s somefile sym_link

then in the Source Tree UI, in the commit histort pane, highlight Uncommitted Changes. You can select sym_link from the "files in the working tree" pane, and in the diff pane, it'll show the content of somefile, not that the file itself (sym_link) is a symlink.

Yes, when you add it, it does appear to stage as a symlink, which is good, but the UI is inconsistent with the file.
fields.summary: symlinks followed rather than represented as symlinks

fields.description:
It would be fantastic to have a list of all pending pull requests.  

We use a small number of mergers on a large number of repos.  They are not always the ones required to approve the pull request as they are not needed for the code review.
fields.summary: Master pull request list

fields.description:
I tag every release of an app, including betas. More recent releases are, naturally, more important.

Unfortunately, they end up on the bottom of the tags list.

It'd be awesome if I could adjust sorting algorithm for the tags. The following would be very useful:
- turn on numerical sort (that correctly sorts 1.9.1, 1.9.2, …, 1.9.9, 1.9.10, 1.9.11)
- turn on descending sort.

Alternatively, it'd be cool to have additional SourceTree-specific metadata, such as tag folders (perhaps smart tag folders that would filter tags), or tag ordering.
fields.summary: Sorting order for Git and Mercurial tags

fields.description: 1.6.0b1 has disabled the Log Selected context menu option in the working copy (staged and unstaged). It continues to work in the commit details pane and in the main menu.
fields.summary: Log Selected is incorrectly disabled in context menu in working copy

fields.description: Via AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/153014/keyboard-shortcut-for-expand-all
fields.summary: Keyboard shortcut for "Expand all"

fields.description: Currently when you click on commit row - displayed small animated progress indicator and than loading commit details. It will be good not showing this indicator for very fast (short) action - for example make delay before showing indicator at least 250-400 ms. And show indicator only for action  that take longer time than 250-400 ms.
fields.summary: Loading progress indicator always showing even for fast action
Invalid spacing characters are rendered as spaces

fields.description: This option should be the equivalent of doing a rebase interactive without specifying the SHA of the commit. The menu item should say something like "Interactive rebase ahead commits" or something more succinct yet understandable. This option should be available as it guarantees the user will only rebase commits ahead of their remote tracking branch.
fields.summary: interactive rebase actions menu item

fields.description: Can't currently have spaces in path in SourceTree app otherwise GRI fails
fields.summary: Spaces in GRI paths cause fault

fields.description: If a row is selected and you context menu a separate row, the context is wrong. It refers the selected row when it should refer to the row you've clicked.
fields.summary: Context menu click on GRI

fields.description: You should be able to hit escape for cancel or cmd+enter to enter the new message for the commit in GRI.
fields.summary: Shortcuts for GRI

fields.description: Should re-build the message if it hasn't been edited
fields.summary: Text keeps getting appended when dropping rows in GRI

fields.description: Currently there's no button to re-register.
fields.summary: Should be able to "Re-register"

fields.description: The title of the window reflects the repository name. It should show a list of the file names. This should be put underneath the title bar as a list of files. The title should be "Log: Multiple Files"
fields.summary: Multiple file log window title

fields.description:
Add a feature in the file diff view, to be able to mark a single or multiple files as read or reviewed.

Reason: most of the time I'm using the file diff view for reviewing changes other people made. It's incredibly hard to do when the file diff view contains hundreds of files. Being able to Mark file diffs as read, greatly improves the reviewing capability of the view.
fields.summary: Mark as read / reviewed per file diff

fields.description:
A few users have been confused when they 'close' the file list in the log view and wonder why their diff doesn't show all the files for that log entry. Need to find a better way to show it's been completely minimised.

See attached screenshot to see what happens. It's very difficult to tell it has been resized so you're unable to see it.
fields.summary: "Closing" (minimising) file list is confusing for users

fields.description:
Via Twitter from Dmitriy Likhten:

https://twitter.com/DmitriyLikhten/status/316537695881019392
https://twitter.com/DmitriyLikhten/status/316178697877090304

Discussions on a user's experience with the interface and suggestions for improvement.
fields.summary: Usability / User Interface Enhancements (Twitter request)

fields.description:
I have external diff and merge tools that I prefer to use configured in my git config. The tools I prefer to use are different depending on if I'm at the CLI or in a GUI such as SourceTree.

Nonetheless, SourceTree only allows me to change away from a default external tool iff it has permission to edit my global configuration files.

If a tool has been configured with the permissions enabled, then the permissions removed, SourceTree reverts to using the default.
fields.summary: Setting external tools without allowing modification

fields.description: For images a preview is displayed in the diff pane, either of the before image or the after image. It would be really useful to have the option to display both.
fields.summary: Add an options to display both before and after images in the diff pane

fields.description: I use iTerm instead of Terminal for many, many reasons.  Please allow choice of terminal program to use on toolbar button.
fields.summary: Allow iTerm to be used instead of Terminal for "Terminal" toolbar item

fields.description: Looks like some translations have been missed out when adding the borders to make them look cleaner.
fields.summary: Borders on translations

fields.description: Instead uses working copy changes instead of staged changes when selected.
fields.summary: External diff doesn't work correctly with ignore whitespace

fields.description:
I think it's very minor, but better to log into Jira instead of bugging you guys on twitter :)

In About dialog the version is displayed twice. Most apps use a build number in braces, but if it's not available it's better to remove the duplication

It will be also nice to update copyright year

Thanks!
fields.summary: About dialog

fields.description: Most users are used to human-order sorting and will think that a branch is not there instead of looking for it at the beginning of the list (having branche names starting with a number).
fields.summary: Sort branches which names start with a number by human-order

fields.description:
I have some file on my remote repository which is a binary file.
I've changed the file to be a symlink in my local repository.
The file shows as unchanged in SourceTree.
If I rename the file it is properly shown as untracked and the original file shows as deleted.
fields.summary: Locally changed file from binary to symlink shows as unchanged in SourceTree

fields.description: As with other help links...
fields.summary: No help links work in latest ST version

fields.description:
If a cherry-pick failed then it actually awaits for you to continue or abort, but we don't seem to be detecting this. The next time the user attempts to do a cherry-pick they can't continue without going to the terminal.

Also, Git allows cherry-picking from the current branch, you should use reset for a specific revision instead for that. If you do specify a revision of a commit on your current branch it just fails and thinks it's still in progress. There must be a reason for this, but IMO it should return an error and abort the cherry-pick. Instead, the user has to manually abort from the terminal.

---

error: a cherry-pick or revert is already in progress
hint: try "git cherry-pick (--continue | --quit | --abort)"
fatal: cherry-pick failed
fields.summary: In-progress cherry-picking detection + stop cherry-picking from current branch

fields.description:
When selecting multiple commits, right clicking, selecting "Cherry Pick" and confirming, there is an error.

In my case (I selected three commits of another branch that I wanted to cherry-pick into the development branch), the full error is:

{quote}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false cherry-pick 5c128c87d85cd19e6eac84d584e92a39eac43acc 7d0c0c68d0a0b7ce37d67e84b1742201c141a00c fc8f400b997ed12d37d0ec06f08028a20ddd71ae 
error: a cherry-pick or revert is already in progress
hint: try "git cherry-pick (--continue | --quit | --abort)"
fatal: cherry-pick failed
Completed with errors, see above
{quote}
fields.summary: Cherry-picking multiple commits fails

fields.description:
When using an external console and commit to SVN there (git svn dcommit), the numbered badge over the push icon is not updated correctly. The rest of the GUI is.

Pre-conditions:
- I have a git-svn repository. I am not sure if the same problem exists for pure git repositories
- The repository is in sync with the SVN server

Steps to reproduce:
1. Commit some changes in SourceTree. The numbered push badge indicates "1".
2. In an external console, use "git svn dcommit"
3. The numbered push badge still indicates "1".

Pressing Cmd+R in SourceTree refreshes the view, but the badge number is still incorrect. Even when quitting SourceTree and restarting the application, the badge still indicates "1".

When pressing the push icon, an empty commit is done and the badge is correctly updated.
fields.summary: Badge not updated when committing to SVN in external console

fields.description: When there are uncommitted changes from a "Reverse" and another "Reverse" is attempted, Git does not allow the operation until the uncommitted changes are committed. The error message shown [displays "patch does not apply"|^screenshot1.png]. It would be nice if SourceTree could display a better error message indicating the origin of the error.
fields.summary: Better Error Messages for Reversing Uncommitted Changes

fields.description:
In the Log/History view, when I have uncommitted changes (and also files that are not added to the index), I'd like to select more files (using Shift/Ctrl) and add them to the index in one step. (-> select some, right click, add to index)
I know that there's a button to add them all, but that's not what I want. (What if there are some that I don't need to add, but many I do?)


I know it's possible, because Eclipse with EGit can do this.
fields.summary: Allow to select multiple files & add to index
